items.description: River Ray and Swinbourne for West Swindon area to above Water Eaton
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today will remain dry for most places. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will be clearing debris from weed/trash screens across the area in anticipation of further potentially heavy rainfall tomorrow.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today will remain dry for most places. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will be clearing debris from weed/trash screens across the area in anticipation of further potentially heavy rainfall tomorrow.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Flooding is possible - be prepared
Small, flashier rivers and streams like the River Wey may respond to heavy rainfall passing through the area in the early hours of Sunday 23/10/22. This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of potential localised heavy rainfall between 04:00 AM on 23/10/22 and 06:00 AM on 23/10/22. Given the unpredictable nature of the rain storm, there is low confidence in the locations and impacts of rainfall at this point. Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams. Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/10/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the upper River Wey as a result of localised thunderstorms. Flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is possible tomorrow morning, 23/10/22, especially in the Bordon area, if the heavier showers occur. 
Thunderstorms are forecast in the early hours of Sunday morning and then again during Sunday afternoon, and showers may become organised into bands of rain. However there is low confidence over exact timing and locations. Once the risk of thunderstorms has passed on Sunday evening, 23/10/22, we expect river levels to begin falling, but levels do remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow, 23/10/22, by 11:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Stourbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall throughout this morning (23/10/2022).  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout today. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until later this afternoon. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Stafford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over night. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 10:00 today, 23/10/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday 24/10/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/10/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Clomoney Way river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning, 23/10/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to Horsbere Brook, Wotton Brook, River Twyver, River Sud, Whaddon Brook, Daniels Brook & Dimore Brook. Locations that may be affected include Longlevens, Wotton, Barnwood & Upton St Leonards.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 this evening on 23/10/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Longbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected between today, 23/10/2022.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Rea between Longbridge and Nechells including Northfield, Kings Norton, Lifford, Stirchley, Selly Park and Digbeth   
We are closely monitoring the situation. We expect river levels to rise until later this afternoon. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/10/2022, or as the situation changes.
